Yes, the ninth circuit will have to re-decide the Stewart case. Stewart was a combined Commerce Clause and Second Amendment case. The ninth circuit upheld his conviction against the Second Amendment challenge and cited its Locklear decision for the position that Stewart did not have an individual Second Amendment RKBA. But Stewart had another grounds for appeal. Stewart added the commerce clause violation claim to his Second Amendment claim. He claimed that the statute he was prosecuted under (18 U.S.C. § 922, cited above in my earlier post on this thread), could not be applied to homemade machine guns. The reason for this claim is this: when Congress passed this machine gun ban it had to claim the authority to do so came from its power to regulate interstate commerce. That is, commerce between "foreign nations" and "among the several states" as well as with Indian tribes. Stewart used raw material items obtained in interstate commerce to construct homemade machineguns, which remained thereafter in his possession and did not re-enter interstate commerce. The Ninth Circuit accepted this appeal argument and declared that applying the ban on possession to homemade weapons kept out of interstate commerce by the maker is an unconstitutional extension of Congress' interstate commerce regulatory power. The bottom line is that the ninth circuit said Stewart had no individual RKBA, but at the same time the statute banning his possession of the machineguns could not be used to prosecute him because it violated the interstate commerce clause. The Government appealed the commerce clause ruling (and this was the only issue presented to SCOTUS). SCOTUS remanded the case back without a decision. 
 Now it is not uncommon for SCOTUS to have several cases appealed to it that deal with similar constitutional arguments, and there were other interstate commerce clause cases pending at the same time as Stewart. One of those (which also arose out of the ninth circuit) was Gonzales v. Raich (which was formerly called Ashcroft v. Raich). SCOTUS decided this case before it got to Stewart. Raich was the California medical marijuana case, where home growers challenged Congress' claim to be able to regulate home grown marijuana through the interstate commerce clause. The ninth circuit used the same logic it applied in Stewart to rule Congress cannot use its interstate commerce clause regulatory power to prohibit home grown marijuana that does not enter interstate commerce. SCOTUS overturned that decision and said Congress can regulate home grown marijuana through its interstate commerce power. Because the marijuana case applies the same constitutional law as that challenged in Stewart, SCOTUS then remanded Stewart back to the ninth circuit with a command that it re-decide that case similarly to the SCOTUS' opinion in Raich. To quote the remand by SCOUTS: "This Court's decision in Raich is therefore likely to shed significant light on the proper disposition of respondent's as-applied constitutional challenge to 18 U.S.C. 922(o)." When SCOTUS makes new law like this it is very common for it to kick all pending cases which have similar legal issues back to the Circuit courts with the not to subtle hint to re-decide the case and get with the program.
 
 The case will be re-decided in the ninth circuit by the same judges, except perhaps one of the ninth's original deciding judges may not rehear it because she was on temporary loan from another Court and may not be back when it is re-decided. I can't say if the ninth will take SCOTUS' hint and change its opinion, because the ninth has a history, particularly in criminal procedure cases, of ignoring SCOTUS (which irks the hell out of SCOTUS-the justices seem to delight in telling the ninth it is wrong in criminal constitutional law cases). As far as the commerce clause challenge goes I don't think it really matters. If the ninth sticks to its guns then the government will appeal to SCOTUS again and it would slap the ninth circuit down and rule that Congress can use the interstate commerce clause to ban the possession of home made machine guns (although Alito questioned this authority in a similar case, which led the Brady Campaign to label him "machine gun Sammy" during his confirmation hearings). 
 
 I don't know enough about federal appellate procedure rules to know if the Second Amendment claim is preserved, because the only issue appealed to SCOTUS was the commerce clause challenge. Assuming that Stewart has not procedurally defaulted his Second Amendment claim, then if Stewart looses round two of the commerce clause fight he may be able to appeal the ninth's ruling on the Second Amendment question to SCOTUS as well.
 
 See the original ninth circuit decision in Stewart, which was appealed to SCOTUS, here: http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/data2/circs/9th/0210318p.pdf
 
 See SCOTUS' decision in the similar interstate commerce clause test case of Gonzales v. Raich here: http://wid.ap.org/scotus/pdf/03-1454P.ZO.pdf
 
 See SCOTUS' opinion remanding Stewart back to the ninth circuit "in light" of Raich: http://www.usdoj.gov/osg/briefs/2004/2pet/7pet/2004-0617.pet.aa.html

Stewart's attorneys will be allowed to argue that the circumstances of the marijuana in Raich are different from the gun in his case. I don't know how well that argument will be received by the Ninth Cir, but if the Ninth rules in his favor on that commerce clause question then it will end up back at SCOTUS, which seems ready to say Congress can use commerce clause power to regulate Stewart's machine guns.
 
 Let me turn to U.S. v. Miller for a moment. This is how that Court described the term "militia":
 
 "The signification attributed to the term Militia appears from the debates in the Convention, the history and legislation of the Colonies and the States, and the writings of approved commentators. These show plainly enough that the militia comprised all males physically capable of acting in concert for the common defense. "A body of citizens enrolled for military discipline." And further, that ordinarily when called for service these men were expected to appear bearing arms supplied by themselves and of a kind in common use at the time." U.S. v. Miller, 307 U.S. 174, 179 (1939).
 
 (Note that one of the "writings of approved commentators" cited by the Court was former Justice Joseph Story's work in which he claimed that the right to keep and bear arms "has justly been considered, as the palladium of the liberties of a republic." 3 J. Story, Commentaries º 1890, p. 746 (1833))
 
 This decision is often mischaracterized as supporting the view that the RKBA only protects the right of enrolled militia members to keep/bear their sanctioned militia arms. Yet Miller was not a member of any militia. He was a private citizen who got caught with a sawed-off shotgun while bootlegging. If SCOTUS wanted to decide that the RKBA protects only militia members, then it would have issued a very short opinion that said as much and would have dismissed the case on the grounds that Miller, because he was a private citizen and not an enrolled militia member, lacked standing to present a Second Amendment infringement claim.
 
 Regarding the shotgun Miller possessed, this is how SCOTUS decided that issue:
 
 "In the absence of any evidence tending to show that possession or use of a "shotgun having a barrel of less than eighteen inches in length" at this time has some reasonable relationship to the preservation or efficiency of a well regulated militia, we cannot say that the Second Amendment guarantees the right to keep and bear such an instrument. Certainly, it is not within judicial notice that this weapon is any part of the ordinary military equipment or that its use could contribute to the common defense." Id. at 178.
 
 Now evidence in cases like this is presented at the trial court level in the district court. In this case, Miller never presented any evidence for his 2nd. Amendment claim. Instead, an activist judge on his own ruled the NFA violated the 2nd. Amendment and invited an appeal. Miller absconded during the appeal process, and no one appeared to argue his case for him. The Court heard only from the government. The "in the absence" comment that starts SCOTUS' analysis is a clear swipe at the defendant's failure to present any evidence below or even have anyone argue his case for him.
 
 In the end, what Miller suggests is private citizens have a RKBA, and that the scope of the right is defined by whether the weapon is "part of the ordinary military equipment or that its use could contribute to the common defense."
